title: Jared Leto thinks someone stole his Met Gala wax-replica head
text:
Jared had no problem slaying the Notes on Camp theme (Picture: Ricky Vigil/GC Images)

Jared Leto thinks someone stole his head.

No, really.

The 47-year-old is convinced someone took the decapitated Gucci head he used as an accessory during the Met Gala in May.

Speaking to GQ, Jared said: ‘I think someone may have stolen it. If anyone out there finds it, bring it into your nearest Gucci store in exchange for a pair of dirty sneakers.’

Considering the wax-like replica cost around $11,000 (£9,000) to make, we’re surprised he’s not a little more upset.

To be fair, it might not have even been stolen considering Jared just has ‘no idea’ where it is, which led him to that conclusion.

Not only did the Suicide Squad star collaborate with Gucci for the accessory, he also worked with them for the entire jaw-dropping ensemble.

Yeah, this head (Picture: Dimitrios Kambouris/Getty Images for The Met Museum/Vogue)

We’re sure he really misses it (Picture: Dimitrios Kambouris/Getty Images for The Met Museum/Vogue)

He wore a long sleeve silk red gown that had diamonds draped over his chest and body.

Advertisement

The artist looked like a priest with a passion for fashion and it was phenomenal.

Gucci’s creative director Alessandro Michele is close friends with the singer-actor and had Jared partner with the luxury brand many a time.

‘I can’t tell you how grateful I am to be a part of that big, crazy Italian family,’ he said.

The Blade Runner 2049 feels ‘really fortunate’ to work with the creative director as well as the ‘motley crew of artists and craftspeople that he’s put together.’

Jared had also joined forces with Gucci to help him look impeccable for his tour with his band Thirty Seconds To Mars.

‘We looked at photographs, sketches, fabrics, colors,’ the singer said on how he achieved his designs. ‘When you’re working with Alessandro and his team, it’s always an adventure, it’s always inspired, and the process is filled with a lot of passion and creativity.’
